February 1922.SECRET.CP. 3746.CABINET.SPECIAL WEEKLY REPORT ON UNEMPLOYMENT.No. 57.WEEK ENDED EEBBTJARY 10, 1922.THE SITUATION.The position in industry generally remains the same. Employment in coal-mining shows little change. The improvement recorded in the iron and steel industry is very slight, and the position is very unstable. In shipping and marine engineering there is little new work being carried out, but a certain amount of activity in repairing is reported on the Thames and in the South Wales ports. The improvement in the woollen trade is maintained, but there is no change in the situation in the cotton industry. The hosiery trade, however, continues to be brisk. General engineering is still very depressed. The improvement recorded in the motor and cycle section is very slight. Employment in the tinplate trade remains the same. There are no signs of improved employment in the building industry. The improve-ment in the tanning and linoleum industries in Lancashire is continued.T. J. [from autumn 1920 to autumn 1921.]cabinet unemployment committee,The prospect of a severe trade depression first became evident in the early autumn of 1920. On the 13th August, 1920, there was a special discussion at a meeting of the Cabinet, when the Cabinet Unemployment Committee was appointed to consider the whole question and devise means for relieving unemployment.[This Committee has since been in constant session and has, up to the 10th February, 1922, held 42 meetings.The problem of unemployment in one form or another has also been before the Cabinet on 56 occasions between the 13th August, 1920, and the 10th February, 1922.] b '(a.) unemployment insurance.An Unemployment Insurance Bill of general scope was passed into law on the 9th August, 1920, and came into operation on the 8th November following. The Act applied compulsory insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons as compared with 4,000,000 previously. Subsequent amending Acts modified the conditions as regards rates of benefit and the amount thereof which could be drawn. Contributions were also increased and authority given to borrow money from the Treasury up to 20,000,000.table showing amount paid out in unemployment benefit during the period november 8, 1920, to february 4, 1922,eb.446651 332471 892Source of Contribution.
